content.raw: It looks like ODE may also be [missing the rotation](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/157c748526b88519100e8411cc9157ea3e3d54e7/gazebo/physics/ode/ODELink.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ODELink.cc-402).
content.html: It looks like ODE may also be missing the rotation.

content.raw:
For ODE the rotation is taken care of in the `MOI(~)` function. It's not obvious just from looking at that line of code, but `MOI(~)` also accounts for the rotation of the `inertial` object's inertial frame.

DART can't really use the `MOI(~)` function the way that ODE does because the `MOI(~)` function also applies the parallel axis theorem to the Moment of Inertia, but DART takes care of that itself since you provide DART with the center of mass location. All we need to do for DART is rotate the moment of inertia's coordinate frame to match the link frame.
content.html:
For ODE the rotation is taken care of in the MOI(~) function. It's not obvious just from looking at that line of code, but MOI(~) also accounts for the rotation of the inertial object's inertial frame.

DART can't really use the MOI(~) function the way that ODE does because the MOI(~) function also applies the parallel axis theorem to the Moment of Inertia, but DART takes care of that itself since you provide DART with the center of mass location. All we need to do for DART is rotate the moment of inertia's coordinate frame to match the link frame.

content.raw: Ah, I see. Thanks. I though that by giving an identity quaternion it was missing the rotation. But MOI takes the difference between the given pose (cog offset) and cog pose, which leaves just the rotation.
content.html: Ah, I see. Thanks. I though that by giving an identity quaternion it was missing the rotation. But MOI takes the difference between the given pose (cog offset) and cog pose, which leaves just the rotation.

content.raw: I think it works the same way, since it stores the pose offset from Link frame to Inertial frame (not the world frame) and just pre and post multiplies by Rotation matrices. I'll try making a patch to illustrate my thought
content.html: I think it works the same way, since it stores the pose offset from Link frame to Inertial frame (not the world frame) and just pre and post multiplies by Rotation matrices. I'll try making a patch to illustrate my thought

content.raw:
The MOI function applies parallel axis theorem, which is a totally reasonable thing to do, except DART expects the moment of inertia to be in link-frame coordinates with respect to the center of mass (because DART itself automatically applies the parallel axis theorem). Applying the parallel axis theorem at this stage would put the moment of inertia into link-frame coordinates *with respect to the link origin*.

I could carefully construct the `_pose` argument that gets passed in to `MOI(_pose)` such that it will transform the moment of inertia to be with respect to the center of mass in link-frame coordinates, but the end result would be the same as the matrix operation that we're doing here, meanwhile it would require quite a few additional operations whose net effect will be to cancel each other out.
content.html:
The MOI function applies parallel axis theorem, which is a totally reasonable thing to do, except DART expects the moment of inertia to be in link-frame coordinates with respect to the center of mass (because DART itself automatically applies the parallel axis theorem). Applying the parallel axis theorem at this stage would put the moment of inertia into link-frame coordinates with respect to the link origin.

I could carefully construct the _pose argument that gets passed in to MOI(_pose) such that it will transform the moment of inertia to be with respect to the center of mass in link-frame coordinates, but the end result would be the same as the matrix operation that we're doing here, meanwhile it would require quite a few additional operations whose net effect will be to cancel each other out.

content.raw:
I think there's a little confusion because there are many `MOI` functions:

* [gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI(Pose)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/40c062da7dcc0ca6977a420cc7e66cd7a4f9f9eb/gazebo/physics/Inertial.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Inertial.hh-213) uses parallel axis theorem as you state above
* [gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI()](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/40c062da7dcc0ca6977a420cc7e66cd7a4f9f9eb/gazebo/physics/Inertial.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Inertial.hh-257) constructs a matrix from the principal and product components, ie. the matrix in the Inertial frame
* [ignition::math::MassMatrix3::MOI()](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/3d32dca333834b57a188c1eec66ec0f82718cb20/include/ignition/math/MassMatrix3.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#MassMatrix3.hh-225) construct matrix3 from principal and product components, similar to `gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI()`
* [ignition::math::Inertial::MOI()](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/3d32dca333834b57a188c1eec66ec0f82718cb20/include/ignition/math/Inertial.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Inertial.hh-87) express inertia matrix in base frame (rotation only without parallel axis theorem), which I think it what you are doing in this function

sorry for all the confusion
content.html:
I think there's a little confusion because there are many MOI functions:

  • gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI(Pose) uses parallel axis theorem as you state above
  • gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI() constructs a matrix from the principal and product components, ie. the matrix in the Inertial frame
  • ignition::math::MassMatrix3::MOI() construct matrix3 from principal and product components, similar to gazebo::physics::Inertial::MOI()
  • ignition::math::Inertial::MOI() express inertia matrix in base frame (rotation only without parallel axis theorem), which I think it what you are doing in this function

sorry for all the confusion

content.raw:
Ohhh, now I understand. My brain was skipping right over the difference between `gazebo::physics::` and `ignition::math::`. So `ignition::math::Inertial` is a different data structure entirely. You're right, `ignition::math::Inertial::MOI()` does the same thing that I'm doing here.

I think we should consider adoption of Frame Semantics very aggressively at this point to disambiguate this type of confusion.
content.html:
Ohhh, now I understand. My brain was skipping right over the difference between gazebo::physics:: and ignition::math::. So ignition::math::Inertial is a different data structure entirely. You're right, ignition::math::Inertial::MOI() does the same thing that I'm doing here.

I think we should consider adoption of Frame Semantics very aggressively at this point to disambiguate this type of confusion.

content.raw: does this problem manifest with the wrench never being applied or with the `WorldForce` / `WorldTorque` accessors being incorrect?
content.html: does this problem manifest with the wrench never being applied or with the WorldForce / WorldTorque accessors being incorrect?

content.raw: The wrench gets applied correctly and the `WorldForce`/`WorldTorque` accessors are (arguably) correct as well. There is just some ambiguity about what it means to query a simulation engine for the `WorldForce` or the `WorldTorque`. Are we asking for the forces and torques that are about to be applied, or are we asking for the forces and torques that were applied during the last time step? DART interprets it as the former while ODE interprets it as the latter. The default behavior of DART is to clear out the forces and torques after a simulation step has occurred to make it easier for the user to begin applying new forces using `addForce` functions, so by default the forces and torques that were applied prior to the last step forward will no longer be available after the step, unless this default behavior is overridden.
content.html: The wrench gets applied correctly and the WorldForce/WorldTorque accessors are (arguably) correct as well. There is just some ambiguity about what it means to query a simulation engine for the WorldForce or the WorldTorque. Are we asking for the forces and torques that are about to be applied, or are we asking for the forces and torques that were applied during the last time step? DART interprets it as the former while ODE interprets it as the latter. The default behavior of DART is to clear out the forces and torques after a simulation step has occurred to make it easier for the user to begin applying new forces using addForce functions, so by default the forces and torques that were applied prior to the last step forward will no longer be available after the step, unless this default behavior is overridden.

content.raw: Thanks for the clarification. I think we need to be more clear about what `WorldForce` and `WorldTorque` mean in our API's, but I don't have an answer at the moment.
content.html: Thanks for the clarification. I think we need to be more clear about what WorldForce and WorldTorque mean in our API's, but I don't have an answer at the moment.

content.raw:
I see that you used the initializer list. What do you think about an inline initializer?

~~~
public: bool resetAllForcesAfterSimulationStep = true;
~~~
content.html:
I see that you used the initializer list. What do you think about an inline initializer?

public: bool resetAllForcesAfterSimulationStep = true;

content.raw:
I'm a pretty firm believer in using initializer lists rather than in-class initialization. Granted, a big part of that is because historically I've had member variables visible from headers, but that's something we avoid in the Gazebo codebases by using PIMPL, so that argument isn't super relevant here. I still favor initialization lists, because it forces you to see the order in which members are getting initialized right at the locations in the code where they are being initialized, which can be important for catching subtle bugs.

I can certainly see the appeal of initializing inside the class definition, because it allows you to "set and forget", but I think a "set and forget" mentality carries a lot of risks with it. Of course leaving it unset and then accidentally forgetting to ever set it is even riskier, so I don't think there's any clear winner here. So my personal preference is to exercise strict self-discipline by never relying on "set and forget" and always obsessively writing an initialization in every constructor overload immediately after I've introduced a new member variable to a class definition (assuming it's a variable which does not have a sane default initialization). But again, I don't think there's a clear winner.

Edit: Also, you can't always count on it to be possible to perform an in-class initialization (depending on how the member variable defines its constructor and assignment operator), whereas you can always count on the initialization list. So strictly using initialization lists guarantees that all your initializations are happening consistently in one place (or rather, one category of places: the constructor definitions).
content.html:
I'm a pretty firm believer in using initializer lists rather than in-class initialization. Granted, a big part of that is because historically I've had member variables visible from headers, but that's something we avoid in the Gazebo codebases by using PIMPL, so that argument isn't super relevant here. I still favor initialization lists, because it forces you to see the order in which members are getting initialized right at the locations in the code where they are being initialized, which can be important for catching subtle bugs.

I can certainly see the appeal of initializing inside the class definition, because it allows you to "set and forget", but I think a "set and forget" mentality carries a lot of risks with it. Of course leaving it unset and then accidentally forgetting to ever set it is even riskier, so I don't think there's any clear winner here. So my personal preference is to exercise strict self-discipline by never relying on "set and forget" and always obsessively writing an initialization in every constructor overload immediately after I've introduced a new member variable to a class definition (assuming it's a variable which does not have a sane default initialization). But again, I don't think there's a clear winner.

Edit: Also, you can't always count on it to be possible to perform an in-class initialization (depending on how the member variable defines its constructor and assignment operator), whereas you can always count on the initialization list. So strictly using initialization lists guarantees that all your initializations are happening consistently in one place (or rather, one category of places: the constructor definitions).

content.raw:
I liked inline initializers after I learned about them when possible because they are more compact and they keep the default value next to the documentation.

I didn't know this before, but [according to cppreference.com](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/initializer_list#Initialization_order) the order of the initializer list doesn't affect the initialization order of non-static data members. Rather, "non-static data members are initialized in order of declaration in the class definition". It may be less convenient, but it seems safer to me to refer to the class definition to know the order of initialization if that is the main concern about "set and forget".
content.html:
I liked inline initializers after I learned about them when possible because they are more compact and they keep the default value next to the documentation.

I didn't know this before, but according to cppreference.com the order of the initializer list doesn't affect the initialization order of non-static data members. Rather, "non-static data members are initialized in order of declaration in the class definition". It may be less convenient, but it seems safer to me to refer to the class definition to know the order of initialization if that is the main concern about "set and forget".

content.raw: Right, you can't reorder anything in the initializer list, but the compiler will throw a warning if you try to put anything in the initializer list in the wrong order. So 1. you get to see during construction what order everything is being constructed in (which might not be obvious in a header where everything can be spread out), and 2. if your expectation about what order things are being initialized in is wrong, the compiler will warn you about it (although I'd prefer it throw a compilation error, but I'll take what I can get).
content.html: Right, you can't reorder anything in the initializer list, but the compiler will throw a warning if you try to put anything in the initializer list in the wrong order. So 1. you get to see during construction what order everything is being constructed in (which might not be obvious in a header where everything can be spread out), and 2. if your expectation about what order things are being initialized in is wrong, the compiler will warn you about it (although I'd prefer it throw a compilation error, but I'll take what I can get).
